title: 115_hr2493
content: The Act may be cited as the "Conflicts from Political Fundraising Act of 2017". Congress finds that public confidence in the Federal Government relies on officers and employees avoiding conflicts of interest. The risk arises when nominees or appointees have ties to political entities. This concern has increased since the Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission decision in 2010. Since the 2010 Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission decision, corporate political spending has significantly increased, with contributions to entities under section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code remaining undisclosed. This anonymity poses a risk of conflicts of interest, whether spending is public or anonymous. Financial disclosure requirements currently do not mandate reporting of donations to such entities. Current financial disclosure requirements do not mandate reporting of funds donated to political action committees or entities organized under section 501(c)(4) or section 501(c)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code. Conflicts of interest can be addressed through public disclosure to the Office of Government Ethics for negotiation in ethics agreements. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF CERTAIN TYPES OF CONTRIBUTIONS. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a "covered contribution" under the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, specifying it as a payment or deposit of money made by or on behalf of a covered individual to a political organization. The curr_chunk further defines a "covered contribution" as a payment made by or on behalf of a covered individual to a political organization or a tax-exempt organization promoting political activities. The curr_chunk discusses tax-exempt organizations under section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code that promote or oppose changes in Federal laws or regulations. The curr_chunk outlines the process for soliciting written support from individuals or entities subject to Federal laws or regulations for a covered individual nominated for a position. The curr_chunk specifies the federal laws or regulations that apply to a covered individual nominated for a position, including those related to political organizations and specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The curr_chunk discusses payments made to organizations described in specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The curr_chunk defines a 'covered individual' as someone nominated or appointed to a 'covered position'. The curr_chunk specifies that a 'covered individual' refers to someone nominated or appointed to certain high-level positions in the government. A 'covered individual' includes individuals appointed to high-level government positions such as limited term appointees, noncareer appointees in the Senior Executive Service, and positions in the executive branch of the Government of a confidential or policy-determining character under schedule C. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to include disclosure requirements for individuals assuming covered positions, excluding those excluded from section 101(f)(5) application. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to include disclosure requirements for individuals assuming covered positions, excluding those excluded from section 101(f)(5) application. The amendment specifies that individuals leaving a non-covered position and assuming a covered position must file a report within 30 days of assuming the new position. Individuals moving from a non-covered position to a covered position must file a report within 30 days of assuming the new position, including the required information outlined in section 102(j)(2)(A). In section 102, subsection (j) outlines the requirement for individuals transitioning from a non-covered position to a covered position to file a report within 30 days, including specified information. In section 102, subsection (j) defines terms related to reporting requirements for covered individuals receiving gifts from specific entities. The term 'covered gift' refers to a gift made to a covered individual, their spouse, or dependent child by specified entities, which would have required reporting if the individual had to file a report. Reports filed by covered individuals must include details of covered contributions made during the relevant period. A report filed by a covered individual must include details of covered contributions made, including the date, value, person making the contribution, and person receiving it. The report filed by a covered individual must include details of covered contributions, such as the value, name of the contributor, and recipient. Covered contributions made by or on behalf of a covered individual may constitute a conflict of interest, but exemptions can be granted by the Director of the Office of Government Ethics under certain circumstances. The Director can exempt covered contributions from disclosure if no conflict of interest risk is present and integrity is not compromised. Reports by covered individuals must include details of covered gifts received. Requests for reports and ethics agreements by Congress must be fulfilled within 30 days. The Director of the Office of Government Ethics must provide reports and ethics agreements to Congress within 30 days of a written request from the Chairman or Ranking Member of a committee. Rules on ethics agreements issuance by agencies will be promptly issued. Government Ethics will provide reports and ethics agreements to Congress upon request from the Chairman or Ranking Member. The Director of the Office of Government Ethics will issue rules on how agencies should handle disclosed information in ethics agreements with appointed individuals.
